Alan,

Interesting, Are these classified as shiirimono?  It
still seems that this tsuba has a lot of handiwork in
it and looks well done?

Thanks,
Ken

 

--- Alan Bale <abale@...> wrote:

> Hi Kenneth,
> The tsuba is a Nagoya-mono from Owari, as the metal
> is brown and not true shakudo it is from the later
> period, one feature commonly found on Nagoya work
> are the 4 'chips', 2 each out of the sides of the
> nakago-ana at the top and bottom .
> 
> The tsuba might be from a yari blade mounted as a
> tanto or wakizashi.
> Alan
>

>   > Hi all,
>   > 
>   > Picked this up from Germany. It is a beautiful
> Mino
>   > Shakudo Tsuba. I believe the kogai ana is filled
>   > with
>   > copper. It has nice nanako. The edge is
> completely
>   > filled with leaves and flowers,etc. The only
> really
>   > weird thing is that the seppa-dai must have be
> put
>   > on
>   > a pole weapon or something. It has notches put
> in
>   > and
>   > the nakaga ana has been widened. Questions,
> where
>   > would you classify this? I was thinking mid-edo,
> 
>   > but
>   > what would you look for in ko-mino work? I have
>   > been
>   > looking for a piece like this for a long time
> and I
>   > think I did well on the purchase. Comments
> please
>   > (good and bad).
